text:
Believe it or not, I got fed up with my Pixel 3. This is a guy that has been a long time Nexus then Pixel fan for years.

The Pixel 3's low RAM, stuttering UI, slow camera load, and the final straw was the shoddy bluetooth making a pair of galaxy buds unusable.
I traded it to Samsung and got a Galaxy S10e and I'm mostly happy with it. I do miss that sweet sweet camera, but the rest of the phone is actually stable.Ôªø

text:
Pixel Best Camera
Blind Test Knocked out on 1st round.Ôªø
author: pradeep kumar

text: Wish I could like your comment 100x!! Pixel is so damn overrated by these YouTube reviewers. They obviously paid by Google and it's so damn annoying. Most people can't even tell the difference now with phone cameras. That Blind camera test proved that!Ôªø
author: DatBoyC 88

text: @DatBoyC 88 I own Galaxy s9 and have a friend with pixel 3, and I can tell that reviews are not lying, pixel makes best and most consistent shots with lowest effort. It just gives most realistic and consistent colors, but it's hard to appreciate on youtube because you don't know how the place looked in real life. On s9 I always have to tap the screen and adjust colors to get good results, so I end up doing multiple photos with different colors and have to choose one later.Ôªø
author: Alex P

text: @Alex P So if it's not all hype then why did it lose out in the Blind Camera test 1st round? It's because the average person who isn't into photography can't tell the different. Shit even you tubers like MKBHD didn't pick the Pixel in that test and he swears by that phone. Camera phones are so close now that it doesn't matter.Ôªø
author: DatBoyC 88

text: @DatBoyC 88 i know about this test, but there people were comparing compressed pictures on Twitter or Instagram. So the sharpness of the images was hard to see. Also people didn't see the place in real life so it was impossible to judge the colors, so everyone just picked most saturated pictures. It's all about what you want: realistic colors and consistency or just more saturated colors. And for consistently realistic colors nothing beats pixel phones right now. Not a fan of the overall phones, but that camera is actually really good and I agree with reviews on that matter.Ôªø
author: Alex P

text: @Alex P You said the same thing, it's all based on preference! That's what I been saying. I'm sure you know about the DXO marks right? The new Samsung s10 has a higher rating than the Pixel. But like I said it's preference, so ratings don't matter. So it makes no sense for reviewers to keep saying the Pixel is the best.Ôªø
author: DatBoyC 88

text: @DatBoyC 88 Preference after the files were compressed and re-uploaded to social media. if you compare in real life, the pixel images are just so much sharper, it looks better to the eye. When you upload the compressed files to social media, many details are lost. The images that were highly processed (eg make the sky bluer or grass greener or make shadows lighter etc) just looked more appealing on social media. In real life the pixel images do look better imo.Ôªø
author: chinnychinchin89

text: @chinnychinchin89 It's preference and the avg person can't even tell the difference. I took pictures with my old Ass Note 8 camera in Feb at my wife's Bday party, and everyone in the room said they loved my pictures and wanted to know what phone I had. Over hyping a phone camera in 2019 makes no sense when the competition is so close now. Smartphones are now adding more cameras for depth perception, wide angles shots and night modes. Quality of the pictures are too close now to keep hyping the Pixel phone.Ôªø
author: DatBoyC 88

text: @DatBoyC 88 You sound like someone who just hasn't taken photos with a pixel phone. The difference in sharpness and detail is noticeable right away. You can even find videos on youtube where people port the google photos app to different phones like the Note 9 for example, and it's not as good as it would be on the Pixel series, but in many cases you can see for yourself the quality of the picture is better on the ported google photos app vs the native camera app. It's not about the megapixels on the sensor, which don't change much year to year across devices, if at all, but rather the google photo computational photography processing is outperforming the competition.Ôªø
author: chinnychinchin89

text: And FYI I have a Pixel and a Note 9Ôªø
author: chinnychinchin89

text: @chinnychinchin89 I know professional photographers with $500 - $1000 cameras so nothing the Pixel does is mind blowing. And I feel that way about ALL PHONE CAMERAS! It's not the serious, believe what you want it's your preference like I keep saying over and over again. Preferences shouldn't be treated as FACTS! That's all I'm gonna say. Have a good day!Ôªø
author: DatBoyC 88

author: Vineet Jaiswal

text:
Wanna hear a hilarious thing?
Long story short : 
You're not gonna get the best from the Pixel, you know why?
Samsung, Huawei, Oneplus and other Android brands can get the Google Camera, and tweak the settings as they want, noise reduction, Light/Shadows saturation, and also have every feature Google's Camera offers.. So yeah, your Android phone can be almost identical as the Pixel, plus every brand's own advantages (In this case Super Slow mo, 4K60, Super steady, Timelapse, but most importantly PRO mode).
So, if you're experienced enough both cameras you'll know when the Google Camera will do better and when the Stock will do better, as a result you're gonna get almost always the very best shot that your phone can ever get.Ôªø

text: @Taisen's Cool Stuff The 3 part video is on my channel, but I did weeks of research on the best content creation device under $200 (several months ago) & settled on getting a "Like New" Refurb. LG V20 by a reputable phone seller on ebay. I had first paid $200 for a brand new in box V20, but they sent the wrong carrier, so I decided to return it for a refund & get the 'Like New' Sprint version, saving $80. I ended up with a screen burned phone that was more like a 7/10 condition, exchanged it 2x with the same seller, ending up with an even more screen burned Verizon version that's barely tolerable for recording video, not much else... I highly recommend just sticking to "9/10" or 'mint cond.' models less than 2yrs old.Ôªø
